1C28FABF436549669AF84CA8BA4DF66F:
Manage an undo transaction. An undo transaction is defined as all actions which take place when the user selects "undo" a single time.

Your transaction logic should link to the Pending pin, and when done should link back to Finalize or Cancel, at which point the Complete pin will run.

Note: You must call TransactObject before modifying each object that should be included in the undo transaction.

AndroidRuntimeSettings.UpgradeInfoMessage:
<RichTextBlock.TextHighlight>Note to users from 4.6 or earlier</>: We now <RichTextBlock.TextHighlight>GENERATE</> an AndroidManifest.xml when building, so if you have customized your .xml file, you will need to put all of your changes into the below settings. Note that we don't touch your AndroidManifest.xml that is in your project directory.
Additionally, we no longer use SigningConfig.xml, the settings are now set in the Distribution Signing section.

<RichTextBlock.TextHighlight>NOTE</>: You must accept the SDK license agreement (click on button below) to use Gradle if it isn't grayed out.

EnvQueryTestDetails.BoolMatchToolTip: Boolean value to match in order to grant score of 'ScoringFactor'.  Not matching this value will not change score.
EnvQueryTestDetails.Constant:
Final score (for values that 'pass') = ScoringFactor
NOTE: In this case, the score is normally EITHER the ScoringFactor value or zero.
The score will be zero if the Normalized Test Value is zero (or if the test value is false for a boolean query).
Otherwise, score will be the ScoringFactor.
EnvQueryTestDetails.Inverse:
Final score = ScoringFactor * (1.0 - NormalizedItemValue)
Bias towards items with values close to zero.  (Linear, but flipped from 1 to 0 rather than 0 to 1.
EnvQueryTestDetails.Square:
Final score = ScoringFactor * (NormalizedItemValue * NormalizedItemValue)
Bias towards items with big values.
EnvQueryTestDetails.Square root:
Final score = ScoringFactor * Sqrt(NormalizedItemValue)
Non-linearly bias towards items with big values.
EnvQueryTestDetails.FloatFilterMaxForClampingRowToolTip: See Filter Thresholds under the Filter tab.  Values higher than this (before normalization) cause the item to be thrown out as invalid.  Values are normalized with this value as the maximum, so items with this value will have a normalized score of 1.
EnvQueryTestDetails.FloatFilterMinForClampingRowToolTip: See Filter Thresholds under the Filter tab.  Values lower than this (before clamping) cause the item to be thrown out as invalid.  Values are normalized with this value as the minimum, so items with this value will have a normalized score of 0.

FNiagaraConstants.EmitterInstanceSeed: A random seed that changes with every execution of the emitter instance.
FNiagaraConstants.SubImageIndexDesc: A value from 0 to the number of entries in the table of SubUV images.
FNiagaraConstants.RibbonUVDistanceDesc: Distance from start of ribbon that the particle lies.
FNiagaraConstants.IDDesc: Engine managed particle attribute that is a persistent ID for each particle.
FNiagaraConstants.UniqueIDDesc: Engine managed particle attribute that is a unique ID for each particle. The ID is incremented for each new particle spawned.
FNiagaraConstants.RibbonLinkOrderDesc: Explicit order for linking particles within a ribbon. Particles of the same ribbon id will be connected into a ribbon in incrementing order of this attribute value.
FNiagaraConstants.GlobalSpawnCountScale: Global Spawn Count Scale. Should only be used in System scripts.
FNiagaraConstants.GlobalSystemCountScale: Global System Count Scale. Should only be used in System scripts.
FNiagaraConstants.AlignmentDesc: Imagine the texture having an arrow pointing up, this attribute makes the arrow point towards the alignment axis. Must be used with the SpriteRenderer's CustomAlignment Alignment option.
FNiagaraConstants.SystemSignificanceIndex: Index denoting how significant this system instance is in relation to others of the same system in this scene. e.g. 0 is the most significanct instance.
FNiagaraConstants.FacingDesc: Makes the surface of the sprite face towards a custom vector. Must be used with the SpriteRenderer's CustomFacingVector FacingMode option.
FNiagaraConstants.RibbonU0OverrideDesc: Overrides the U component of the UV0 texture coordinate of a ribbon particle.
FNiagaraConstants.RibbonU1OverrideDesc: Overrides the U component of the UV1 texture coordinate of a ribbon particle.
FNiagaraConstants.RibbonV0RangeOverrideDesc: Overrives the V range across the width of a ribbon for the UV0 texture coordinate of a particle.
FNiagaraConstants.RibbonV1RangeOverrideDesc: Overrives the V range across the width of a ribbon for the UV1 texture coordinate of a particle.
FNiagaraConstants.LocalToWorldTransposeDesc: Owning component's local space to world space transform matrix transposed.
FNiagaraConstants.LocalToWorldNoScaleDesc: Owning component's local space to world space transform matrix with scaling removed.
FNiagaraConstants.LocalToWorldDesc: Owning component's local space to world space transform matrix.
FNiagaraConstants.WorldToLocalTransposeDesc: Owning component's world space to local space transform matrix transposed.
FNiagaraConstants.WorldToLocalNoScaleDesc: Owning component's world space to local space transform matrix with scaling removed.
FNiagaraConstants.WorldToLocalDesc: Owning component's world space to local space transform matrix.
FNiagaraConstants.RibbonFacingDesc: Sets the facing vector of the ribbon at the particle position, or the side vector the ribbon's width is extended along, depending on the selected facing mode.
FNiagaraConstants.RibbonIDDesc: Sets the ribbon id for a particle. Particles with the same ribbon id will be connected into a ribbon.
FNiagaraConstants.RibbonTwistDesc: Sets the ribbon twist for a particle, in degrees.
FNiagaraConstants.RibbonWidthDesc: Sets the ribbon width for a particle, in UE4 units.
FNiagaraConstants.DynamicMaterialParameterDesc: The 4-float vector used to send custom data to renderer.
FNiagaraConstants.XAxisDesc: The X-axis of the owning component.
FNiagaraConstants.ScaleParamDesc: The XYZ scale of the non-sprite based particle.
FNiagaraConstants.YAxisDesc: The Y-axis of the owning component.
FNiagaraConstants.ZAxisDesc: The Z-axis of the owning component.
FNiagaraConstants.NormalizedAgeDesc: The age in seconds divided by lifetime in seconds. Useful for animation as the value is between 0 and 1.
FNiagaraConstants.MeshOrientParamDesc: The axis-angle rotation to be applied to the mesh particle.
FNiagaraConstants.PivotOffsetParamDesc: The central pivot point of the sprite in UV space
FNiagaraConstants.EngineSystemTickCount: The current tick of this system simulation.
FNiagaraConstants.LODDistanceFraction: The distance fraction between this system and it's max culling distance defined in it's EffectType scalabiltiy settings.
FNiagaraConstants.LODDistance: The distance to use in LOD scaling/culling. Typically, the distance to the nearest camera.
FNiagaraConstants.ExecutionState: The execution state of the systems owner. Takes precedence over the systems internal execution state.
FNiagaraConstants.EngineEmitterSimulationPosition: The frame of reference space which the Emitter simulation is relative to. Is 0,0,0 for an Emitter in local space, and is Engine.Owner.Position for an Emitter in world space.
FNiagaraConstants.EmitterSpawnCountScale: The global spawn count scale, based on fx.NiagaraGlobalSpawnCountScale.
FNiagaraConstants.MeshIndexParamDesc: The index of the mesh to use to render this particle.
FNiagaraConstants.ExecCountDesc: The index of this particle in the read buffer.
FNiagaraConstants.LifetimeParamDesc: The lifetime of a particle in seconds.
FNiagaraConstants.SystemNumEmitters: The number of emitters attached to this system. Should only be used in System scripts.
FNiagaraConstants.SystemNumEmittersAlive: The number of emitters still alive attached to this system. Should only be used in System scripts.
FNiagaraConstants.SystemNumInstances: The number of instances of the this system currently ticking. Should only be used in System scripts.
FNiagaraConstants.EmitterNumParticles: The number of particles for this emitter at the beginning of simulation. Should only be used in Emitter scripts.
FNiagaraConstants.EnginePositionDesc: The owning component's position in world space.
FNiagaraConstants.EngineRotationDesc: The owning component's rotation in world space.
FNiagaraConstants.EngineScaleDesc: The owning component's scale in world space.
FNiagaraConstants.EngineVelocityDesc: The owning component's velocity in world space.
FNiagaraConstants.SpriteRotDesc: The screen aligned roll of the particle in degrees.
FNiagaraConstants.SpriteSizeDesc: The size of the sprite quad.
FNiagaraConstants.TimeSinceRendered: The time in seconds that have passed since this system was last rendered.
FNiagaraConstants.EmitterTotalSpawnedParticles: The total number of particles spawned for this emitter at the beginning of this simulation. Should only be used by the particle spawn script the assign unique IDs.
FNiagaraConstants.VelocityDesc: The velocity in cm/s of the particle.
FNiagaraConstants.LightEnabledParamDesc: This can be used with the Light renderer control the spawn-rate of lights on a per-particle basis.
FNiagaraConstants.EngineRealTimeDesc: Time in seconds since level began play, but IS NOT paused when the game is paused, and IS NOT dilated/clamped.
FNiagaraConstants.EngineTimeDesc: Time in seconds since level began play, but IS paused when the game is paused, and IS dilated/clamped.
FNiagaraConstants.EngineDeltaTimeDesc: Time in seconds since the last tick.
FNiagaraConstants.EngineSystemTimeDesc: Time in seconds since the system was first created. Managed by the NiagaraSystemInstance in code.
FNiagaraConstants.VisibilityTag: Used for selecting renderers to use when rendering this particle. Without this, the particle will render in all renderers
FNiagaraConstants.ComponentRenderEnabledParamDesc: Used to check if component rendering should be enabled on a per-particle basis. Without this, the each particle will spawn a component.
FNiagaraConstants.AliveParamDesc: Used to determine whether or not this particle instance is still valid or if it can be deleted.
FNiagaraConstants.MaterialRandomParamDesc: Used to drive the Particle Random node in the Material Editor. Without this set, any Particle Randoms will get 0.0.
FNiagaraConstants.LightExponentParamDesc: Used to drive the attenuation of the light when using a Light renderer without inverse squared falloff enabled.
FNiagaraConstants.LightRadiusParamDesc: Used to drive the radius of the light when using a Light renderer.
FNiagaraConstants.LightVolumetricScatteringParamDesc: Used to drive the volumetric scattering intensity of the light when using a Light renderer.
FNiagaraConstants.UVScalerParamDesc: Used to multiply the generated UVs for Sprite renderers.
FNiagaraConstants.CamOffsetParamDesc: Used to offset position in the direction of the camera. The value is multiplied by the direction vector from the camera to the particle.

Fracture.FractureToolClusterTooltip: Cluster Voronoi Fracture creates additional points around a base Voronoi pattern, creating more variation.  Click the Fracture Button to commit the fracture to the geometry collection.
Fracture.FractureToolDeleteEmbeddedGeometryToolti: Delete selected embedded geometry nodes. If a cluster or rigid node is selected, all child embedded geometry nodes are deleted.
Fracture.FractureToolSelectNoneTooltip: Deselects all Bones in the GeometryCollection.
Fracture.FractureToolAddEmbeddedGeometryTooltip: Embed selected static mesh as passive geometry parented to nearest bone. Will be lost if GeometryCollection is Reset!
Fracture.FractureToolGenerateAssetTooltip: Generate Geometry Collection Asset from static meshes contained in selected actors.
Fracture.FractureToolPlaneCutTooltip: Planar fracture can be used to make cuts along a plane in your Geometry Collection. You can apply noise to planar cuts for more organic results.  Click the Fracture Button to commit the fracture to the geometry collection.
Fracture.FractureToolRadialTooltip: Radial Voronoi Fracture create a radial distribution of Voronoi cells from a center point (for example, a wrecking ball crashing into a wall).  Click the Fracture Button to commit the fracture to the geometry collection.
Fracture.FractureToolResetTooltip: Reset Geometry Collection Asset to its initial unfractured state.
Fracture.FractureToolSelectNeighborsTooltip: Select all bones adjacent to the currently selected bones.
Fracture.FractureToolSelectSiblingsTooltip: Select all bones at the same levels as the currently selected bones.
Fracture.FractureToolSelectAllInClusterTooltip: Select all bones with the same parent as selected bones.
Fracture.FractureToolSelectAllTooltip: Selects all Bones in the GeometryCollection
Fracture.FractureToolSliceTooltip: The Slice Voronoi fracture method enables you to define the number of X, Y, and Z slices, along with providing random angle and offset variation.  Click the Fracture Button to commit the fracture to the geometry collection.
Fracture.FractureToolBrickTooltip: This type of fracture enables you to define a pattern to perform the fracture, along with the forward and up axis in which to fracture. You can also adjust the brick length, height, or depth to provide varying results.  Click the Fracture Button to commit the fracture to the geometry collection.
Fracture.FractureToolUniformTooltip: Uniform Fracture will create pieces of approximately the same volume.  Specify minimum and maximum number of cites.  Using the same Random Seed will produce the same fracture.

FractureAutoCluster.FractureToolAutoClusterToolTip: Automatically group together pieces of a fractured mesh (based on your settings) and assign them within the Geometry Collection.

HeadMountedDisplay.CVarText_MixLayerPriorities:
By default, Face-Locked Stereo Layers are always rendered on top of any other layer position types.
Set this to a non-zero value to disable this behavior (not supported on all platforms.)
HeadMountedDisplay.CVarText_SpectatorScreenMode:
Changes the look of the spectator if supported by the HMD plugin.
 0: disable mirroring
 1: single eye
 2: stereo pair
Numbers larger than 2 may be possible and specify HMD plugin-specific variations.
Negative values are treated the same as 0.
HeadMountedDisplay.CVarText_HiddenAreaMask:
Enable or disable hidden area mask
0: disabled
1: enabled
HeadMountedDisplay.CVarText_EnableDevOverrides: Enables or disables console commands that modify various developer-only settings.
HeadMountedDisplay.CCommandText_EnableHMD: Enables or disables the HMD device. Use 1, True, or Yes to enable, 0, False or No to disable.
HeadMountedDisplay.CCommandText_EnableStereo: Enables or disables the stereo rendering. Use 1, True, or Yes to enable, 0, False or No to disable.
HeadMountedDisplay.CCommandText_TrackingOrigin: Floor or 0 - tracking origin is at the floor, Eye or 1 - tracking origin is at the eye level.
HeadMountedDisplay.CCommandText_WorldToMeters: Get or set the current world to meters scale.
HeadMountedDisplay.CCommandText_ForceTracking:
If set, head tracking is enabled even when stereo rendering is disabled.
May not be supported by all XR implementations.
HeadMountedDisplay.CCommandText_HMDVersion: Prints version information for the current HMD device.
HeadMountedDisplay.CVarText_HMDStatus: Reports the current status of the head tracking.
HeadMountedDisplay.CVarText_HMDResetPosition: Reset the position of the head mounted display.
HeadMountedDisplay.CVarText_HMDReset:
Reset the rotation and position of the head mounted display.
Pass in an optional yaw for the new rotation in degrees.
HeadMountedDisplay.CVarText_HMDResetOrientation:
Reset the rotation of the head mounted display.
Pass in an optional yaw for the new rotation in degrees .
HeadMountedDisplay.CVarText_ShowTrackingSensors:
Show or hide the location and coverage area of the tracking sensors
Use 1, True, or Yes to enable, 0, False or No to disable.

MobileLauncherProfileWizard.DestinationPageDescription:
This wizard will create two Project Launcher profiles designed to help you package your {PlatformName} game so that the majority of the game's contents, and future content updates, can distributed to your users via HTTP from a Cloud provider or Content Distribution Network when the user launches your app. The first profile is used to generate a small {PlatformName} executable for distribution to the {PlatformStore}. This executable will contain Unreal Engine and your game code, but only the minimum assets required to display the download user interface to the user, while they download your game's latest content to their device. {PlatformDLC}.

The executable needs code added to use the BuildPatchServices module to download the only the necessary chunks to the user's device and reconstruct the contents file before launching your game.
MobileLauncherProfileWizard.AndroidWizardDescription: This wizard will help to create two launcher profiles, one for minimal Android APK and another for downloadable content.
MobileLauncherProfileWizard.IOSWizardDescription: This wizard will help to create two launcher profiles, one for minimal IOS App and another for downloadable content.

NamespaceMetadata.InitialModifierDescription:
A namespace modifier for dataset attributes which when used in
a linked input in an update script will get the initial value from the spawn script.
NamespaceMetadata.PreviousModifierDescription:
A namespace modifier for dataset attributes which when used in
a linked input in an update script will get the value from the start of the update script.
NamespaceMetadata.ModuleModifierDescription:
A namespace modifier which makes that attribute unique to the module
instance by appending the unique module name.
NamespaceMetadata.EmitterModifierDescription: A namespace modifier which specifies that an engine provided parameter comes from the emitter.
NamespaceMetadata.OwnerDescription: A namespace modifier which specifies that an engine provided parameter comes from the owner, or component.
NamespaceMetadata.SystemModifierDescription: A namespace modifier which specifies that an engine provided parameter comes from the system.
NamespaceMetadata.UserDescription:
A read only value which can be initialized per system and
modified externally in the level, by blueprint, or by c++.
NamespaceMetadata.EngineDescription:
A read only value which is provided by the engine.
This value's source can be the simulation itsef
e.g. ExecutionCount, or the owner of the simulation (The component), e.g. (Owner) Scale.
NamespaceMetadata.DataInstanceDescription: A special value which has a single bool IsAlive value, which determines if a particle is alive or not.
NamespaceMetadata.TransientDescription:
A transient value which can be written to and read from from any module.
Transient values do not persist from frame to frame, or between stages, e.g. emitter to particle, or spawn to update.
NamespaceMetadata.ModuleLocalDescription:
A transient value which can be written to and read from within a single module.
Transient values do not persist from frame to frame, or between stages, e.g. emitter to particle, or spawn to update.
NamespaceMetadata.ModuleOutputDescription:
A transient value which the module author has decided might be useful to other modules further down in the stage.
Transient values do not persist from frame to frame, or between stages, e.g. emitter to particle, or spawn to update.
NamespaceMetadata.StackContextDescription:
A value which can be written to and read from from any module.
StackContext values do  persist from frame to frame, or between stages, e.g. emitter to particle, or spawn to update.
They take on the namespace most relevant to where they are used.
System Spawn/Update: "System"
Emitter Spawn/Update: "Emitter".
Particle Spawn/Update/Events: "Particles".
Particle Simulation Stage iterating Particles: "Particles".
Particle Simulation Stage with Iteration Source: Writes to the iteration source directly.

Persistent attribute in the system which is written in a system
 stage and can be read anywhere.

Persistent attribute which is written in a emitter
stage and can be read in emitter and particle stages.
NamespaceMetadata.ParticleDescription:
Persistent attribute which is written in a particle
stage and can be read in particle stages.

Values read from a niagara parameter collection asset.
Read only in a niagara system.

NewPluginWizard.ChoosePluginTemplate: Choose a template and then specify a name to create a new plugin.
NewPluginWizard.ContentOnlyTemplateDesc: Create a blank plugin that can only contain content.
NewPluginWizard.BlankTemplateDesc:
Create a blank plugin with a minimal amount of code.

Choose this if you want to set everything up from scratch or are making a non-visual plugin.
A plugin created with this template will appear in the Editor's plugin list but will not register any buttons or menu entries.
NewPluginWizard.ThirdPartyDesc:
Create a plugin that uses an included third party library.

This can be used as an example of how to include, load and use a third party library yourself.
NewPluginWizard.AdvancedTemplateDesc: Create a plugin that will add a button to the toolbar in the Level Editor that summons an empty standalone tab window when clicked.
NewPluginWizard.BasicTemplateDesc:
Create a plugin that will add a button to the toolbar in the Level Editor.

Start by implementing something in the created "OnButtonClick" event.
NewPluginWizard.BPLibTemplateDesc:
Create a plugin that will contain Blueprint Function Library.

Choose this if you want to create static blueprint nodes.
NewPluginWizard.EditorModeDesc:
Create a plugin that will have an editor mode.

This will include a toolkit example to specify UI that will appear in "Modes" tab (next to Foliage, Landscape etc).
It will also include very basic UI that demonstrates editor interaction and undo/redo functions usage.
NewPluginWizard.ShowPluginContentDirectoryToolTip: Shows the content directory after creation.
NewPluginWizard.EnginePluginButtonToolTip: Toggles whether this plugin will be created in the current project or the engine directory.
NewPluginWizard.ShowOnStartupToolTip: Toggles whether this wizard will show when the editor is launched.

NiagaraDataInterfaceCamera.CPUCameraAccessWarningSummary: Camera properties cannot be previewed on CPU emitters!
NiagaraDataInterfaceCamera.FieldOfViewAngleDescription: Return the camera's field of view in degrees.
NiagaraDataInterfaceCamera.ViewSizeAndInverseSizeDescription: Returns a vec4 - the x and y values are width and height of the view; the z and w values are the inverse width and height.
NiagaraDataInterfaceCamera.TemporalAACurrentDescription: Returns the movement of the current frame view due to AA jittering
NiagaraDataInterfaceCamera.TemporalAAPreviousDescription: Returns the movement of the previous frame view due to AA jittering
NiagaraDataInterfaceCamera.PreViewTranslationDescription: Returns the translation to apply for the various 'Translated XX to XX' transforms.
NiagaraDataInterfaceCamera.IsClosestDescription: Returns true if the given particle ID is one of the closest n particles based on last frame's calculation.
NiagaraDataInterfaceCamera.TranslatedWorldToCameraTransformDescript: Same as 'Translated World To View', but transforms to the camera position instead of the view position.
NiagaraDataInterfaceCamera.CameraToTranslatedWorldTransformDescript: Same as 'View To Translated World', but transforms from the camera position instead of the view position.
NiagaraDataInterfaceCamera.ScreenToTranslatedWorldTransformDescript:
Same as the screen to world transform, but with the assumption that the camera is at the origin.
This allows for more precision of the transform when dealing with big coordinates.
To get the actual world space position, you need to add PreViewTranslation to the transform result.
NiagaraDataInterfaceCamera.TranslatedWorldToClipTransformDescriptio:
Same as world to clip transform, but the camera position is at the origin when camera translation is enabled.
This allows for more precision of the transform when dealing with big coordinates.
To use this transform, you first need to subtract PreViewTranslation from your transform target.
NiagaraDataInterfaceCamera.CameraPositionWorldDescription: The camera position in world space.
NiagaraDataInterfaceCamera.ViewPositionWorldDescription: The camera position in world space.
NiagaraDataInterfaceCamera.RightVectorWorldDescription: The camera's right direction in world space.
NiagaraDataInterfaceCamera.ViewRightVectorDescription: The camera's right direction in world space.
NiagaraDataInterfaceCamera.UpVectorWorldDescription: The camera's up direction in world space.
NiagaraDataInterfaceCamera.ViewUpVectorDescription: The camera's up direction in world space.
NiagaraDataInterfaceCamera.CPUCameraAccessWarning:
The cpu camera is bound to a player controller and will therefore not work correctly in the Niagara viewport.
To correctly preview the effect, use it in the level editor or switch to a GPU emitter.
NiagaraDataInterfaceCamera.ClipToTranslatedWorldTransformDescriptio:
The inverse of the translated world to clip transform. When camera translation is enabled, the transform is such that the camera position is at the origin.
This allows for more precision of the transform when dealing with big coordinates.
To get the actual world space position, you need to add PreViewTranslation to the transform result.
NiagaraDataInterfaceCamera.ViewToTranslatedWorldTransformDescriptio:
The inverse of the translated world to view transform. When camera translation is enabled, the transform is such that the camera position is at the origin.
This allows for more precision of the transform when dealing with big coordinates.
To get the actual world space position, you need to add PreViewTranslation to the transform result.
NiagaraDataInterfaceCamera.MaxValidResultsDescription:
The max number of particles closest to the camera that this function should return true for.
For example, if there are 30 particles and Max Valid Results is set to 10, then this functions returns true for the 10 closest particles.
NiagaraDataInterfaceCamera.ForwardVectorWorldDescription: The world space direction that the camera is pointing.
NiagaraDataInterfaceCamera.ViewForwardVectorDescription: The world space direction that the camera is pointing.
NiagaraDataInterfaceCamera.QueryClosestDescription:
This function checks the previously calculated distance of each particle and then returns true for the closest particles and false for the other ones.
This function needs to be paired with CalculateParticleDistancesCPU to work correctly.
NiagaraDataInterfaceCamera.CalculateDistancesDescription:
This function compares the particle position against the camera position and stores the result to be queried in the next frame.
The results can then be queried with QueryClosestParticlesCPU.
NiagaraDataInterfaceCamera.GetClipSpaceTransformsDescription: This function returns the clip transforms for the current view. Only valid for gpu particles.
NiagaraDataInterfaceCamera.GetNiagaraFOVDescription: This function returns the field of view angle (in degrees) for the active camera. For gpu particles this returns the x axis fov.
NiagaraDataInterfaceCamera.GetCameraPositionDescription: This function returns the position of the currently active camera.
NiagaraDataInterfaceCamera.GetViewPropertiesDescription: This function returns the properties of the current view. Only valid for gpu particles.
NiagaraDataInterfaceCamera.GetViewSpaceTransformsDescription: This function returns the relevant transforms for the current view. Only valid for gpu particles.
NiagaraDataInterfaceCamera.ClipToViewTransformDescription: Transforms a clip space position to view space
NiagaraDataInterfaceCamera.ClipToWorldTransformDescription: Transforms a clip space position to world space
NiagaraDataInterfaceCamera.TranslatedWorldToViewTransformDescriptio:
Transforms a position from world to view, but the view position is assumed to be at the origin.
This allows for more precision of the transform when dealing with big coordinates.
To use this transform, you first need to subtract PreViewTranslation from your transform target.
NiagaraDataInterfaceCamera.ViewToClipTransformDescription: Transforms a view space position to clip space
NiagaraDataInterfaceCamera.ViewToClipNoAATransformDescription: Transforms a view space position to clip space without the temporal AA jittering
NiagaraDataInterfaceCamera.WorldToClipTransformDescription: Transforms a world space position to clip space
NiagaraDataInterfaceCamera.ClipToPreviousClipTransformDescription:
Transforms from a current clip space position to last frame's clip space position.
This can be used to calculate for example post process velocity.

NiagaraDataInterfaceCollisionQuery.CollisionMaterialFrictionDescription: Friction value of surface, controls how easily things can slide on this surface (0 is frictionless, higher values increase the amount of friction).
NiagaraDataInterfaceCollisionQuery.CollisionPosWorldDescription: If the collision is valid, this returns the location of the blocking hit.
NiagaraDataInterfaceCollisionQuery.CollisionNormalDescription: If the collision is valid, this returns the normal at the position of the blocking hit.
NiagaraDataInterfaceCollisionQuery.DistanceToNearestSurfaceDescription: If the query was successful this returns the distance to the nearest surface, otherwise returns 0.
NiagaraDataInterfaceCollisionQuery.FieldGradientDescription: If the query was successful this returns the non-normalized direction to the nearest surface, otherwise returns (0, 0, 0).
NiagaraDataInterfaceCollisionQuery.SceneDepthDescription: If the query was successful this returns the scene depth, otherwise -1.
NiagaraDataInterfaceCollisionQuery.SampleWorldNormalDescription: If the query was successful, this returns the world normal at the sample point. Otherwise returns (0, 0, 1).
NiagaraDataInterfaceCollisionQuery.SamplePosWorldDescription: If the query was successful, this returns the world position that was recalculated from the scene depth. Otherwise returns (0, 0, 0).
NiagaraDataInterfaceCollisionQuery.IsTraceInsideMeshDescription: If true then the trace started in penetration, i.e. with an initial blocking overlap.
NiagaraDataInterfaceCollisionQuery.SkipTraceDescription:
If true then the trace will be skipped completely.
This can be used as a performance optimization, as branch nodes in the graph still execute every path.
NiagaraDataInterfaceCollisionQuery.CustomDepthDescription: Projects a given world position to view space and then queries the custom depth buffer with that position.
NiagaraDataInterfaceCollisionQuery.SceneDepthSignatureDescription: Projects a given world position to view space and then queries the depth buffer with that position.
NiagaraDataInterfaceCollisionQuery.DistanceFieldDescription:
Queries the global distance field for a given world position.
Please note that the distance field resolution gets lower the farther away the queried position is from the camera.
NiagaraDataInterfaceCollisionQuery.CollisionMaterialRestitutionDescription: Restitution or 'bounciness' of this surface, between 0 (no bounce) and 1 (outgoing velocity is same as incoming)
NiagaraDataInterfaceCollisionQuery.CameraPosWorldDescription: Returns the current camera position in world space.
NiagaraDataInterfaceCollisionQuery.CollisionMaterialIndexDescription: Returns the index of the surface as defined in the ProjectSettings/Physics/PhysicalSurface section
NiagaraDataInterfaceCollisionQuery.IsDistanceFieldValidDescription: Returns true if the global distance field is available and there was a valid value retrieved for the given sample position.
NiagaraDataInterfaceCollisionQuery.IsInsideViewDescription: Returns true if the query position could be projected to valid screen coordinates.
NiagaraDataInterfaceCollisionQuery.CollisionValidDescription: Returns true if the trace was not skipped and the trace was blocked by some world geometry.
NiagaraDataInterfaceCollisionQuery.NiagaraDistanceFieldNotEnabledMsg:
The mesh distance field generation is currently not enabled, please check the project settings.
Niagara cannot query the distance field otherwise.
NiagaraDataInterfaceCollisionQuery.PreviousFrameQueryIDDescription:
The query ID returned from the last frame's async trace call.
Regardless if it is a valid ID or not this function call with issue a new async line trace, but it will only return results with a valid ID.
NiagaraDataInterfaceCollisionQuery.NextFrameQueryIDDescription: The query ID to save and use as input to this function in the next frame.
NiagaraDataInterfaceCollisionQuery.TraceChannelDescription: The trace channel to collide against. Trace channels can be configured in the project settings.
NiagaraDataInterfaceCollisionQuery.DepthSamplePosWorldDescription: The world position where the depth should be queried. The position gets automatically transformed to view space to query the depth buffer.
NiagaraDataInterfaceCollisionQuery.FieldSamplePosWorldDescription: The world position where the distance field should be queried.
NiagaraDataInterfaceCollisionQuery.TraceEndWorldDescription: The world position where the line trace should end.
NiagaraDataInterfaceCollisionQuery.TraceStartWorldDescription: The world position where the line trace should start.
NiagaraDataInterfaceCollisionQuery.SigCpuAsyncDescription:
Traces a ray against the world using a specific channel and return the first blocking hit the next frame.
Note that this is the ASYNC version of the trace function, meaning it will not returns the result right away, but with one frame latency.
NiagaraDataInterfaceCollisionQuery.SigCpuSyncDescription: Traces a ray against the world using a specific channel and return the first blocking hit.

NiagaraDataInterfaceIntRenderTarget.AtomicMaxDesc: Atomic max the value to the pixel at the offset, returns the current & previous values.  This opertion is thread safe.
NiagaraDataInterfaceIntRenderTarget.AtomicAddDesc: Atomic min the value to the pixel at the offset, returns the current & previous values.  This opertion is thread safe.
NiagaraDataInterfaceIntRenderTarget.AtomicMinDesc: Atomic min the value to the pixel at the offset, returns the current & previous values.  This opertion is thread safe.
NiagaraDataInterfaceIntRenderTarget.LinearToUVDesc: Converts a linear index into a UV coordinate
NiagaraDataInterfaceIntRenderTarget.LinearToIndexDesc: Converts a linear index into a pixel coordinate
NiagaraDataInterfaceIntRenderTarget.GetSizeDesc: Gets the size of the rendertarget
NiagaraDataInterfaceIntRenderTarget.GetValueDesc: Gets the value from the render target at the pixel offset
NiagaraDataInterfaceIntRenderTarget.SetSizeDesc: Sets the size of the rendertarget
NiagaraDataInterfaceIntRenderTarget.SetValueDesc: Sets the value on the render target at the pixel offset.

NiagaraDataInterfaceMeshRendererInfo.NoRendererSelectedWarning: A Mesh Renderer applied to an emitter in this system is expected to be selected here
NiagaraDataInterfaceMeshRendererInfo.GetMeshLocalBoundsDesc: Retrieves the local bounds of the specified mesh's vertices.
NiagaraDataInterfaceMeshRendererInfo.GetNumMeshesInRendererDesc: Retrieves the number of meshes on the mesh renderer by index, or -1 if the index is invalid.
NiagaraDataInterfaceMeshRendererInfo.RendererDisabledWarning: The selected Mesh Renderer is disabled

NiagaraDataInterfaceOcclusion.VisibilityFractionDescription:
Returns a value 0..1 depending on how many of the samples on the screen were occluded.
For example, a value of 0.3 means that 70% of visible samples were occluded.
If the sample fraction is 0 then this also returns 0.
NiagaraDataInterfaceOcclusion.SampleFractionDescription:
Returns a value 0..1 depending on how many samples were inside the viewport or outside of it.
For example, a value of 0.3 means that 70% of samples were outside the current viewport and therefore not visible.
NiagaraDataInterfaceOcclusion.SamplesPerRingDescription:
The number of samples for each ring inside the circle.
The total number of samples is NumRings * SamplesPerRing.
NiagaraDataInterfaceOcclusion.StepsPerLineDescription: The number of samples to take horizontally. The total number of samples is this value squared.
NiagaraDataInterfaceOcclusion.SampleWindowHeightWorldDescription:
The total height of the sample rectangle in world space.
If the particle is a camera-aligned sprite then this is the sprite height.
NiagaraDataInterfaceOcclusion.SampleWindowWidthWorldDescription:
The total width of the sample rectangle in world space.
If the particle is a camera-aligned sprite then this is the sprite width.
NiagaraDataInterfaceOcclusion.SampleWindowDiameterDescription:
The world space diameter of the circle to sample.
If the particle is a spherical sprite then this is the sprite size.
NiagaraDataInterfaceOcclusion.GetCameraOcclusionRectFunctionDescriptio: This function returns the occlusion factor of a sprite. It samples the depth buffer in a rectangular grid around the given world position and compares each sample with the camera distance.
NiagaraDataInterfaceOcclusion.GetCameraOcclusionCircleFunctionDescript: This function returns the occlusion factor of a sprite. It samples the depth buffer in concentric rings around the given world position and compares each sample with the camera distance.
NiagaraDataInterfaceOcclusion.NumberOfSampleRingsDescription:
This number of concentric rings to sample inside the circle.
The total number of samples is NumRings * SamplesPerRing.
NiagaraDataInterfaceOcclusion.CircleCenterPosDescription: This world space position where the center of the sample circle should be.
NiagaraDataInterfaceOcclusion.RectCenterPosDescription: This world space position where the center of the sample rectangle should be.

NiagaraDataInterfaceSkeletalMesh_BoneSam.GetFilteredSocketOrBoneAtDesc: Gets a filtered socket or bone count from the DI's list.
NiagaraDataInterfaceSkeletalMesh_BoneSam.GetUnfilteredBoneAtDesc: Gets the bone at the passed index from the exlusion of the DI's filter bones list.
NiagaraDataInterfaceSkeletalMesh_BoneSam.GetFilteredBoneAtDesc: Gets the bone at the passed index in the DI's filter bones list.
NiagaraDataInterfaceSkeletalMesh_BoneSam.RandomFilteredSocketOrBoneDesc: Gets the bone for a random filtered socket or bone from the DI's list.
NiagaraDataInterfaceSkeletalMesh_BoneSam.RandomFilteredSocketDesc: Gets the bone for a random socket in the DI's filtered socket list.
NiagaraDataInterfaceSkeletalMesh_BoneSam.GetFilteredSocketBoneAtDesc: Gets the bone for the socket at the passed index in the DI's filtered socket list.
NiagaraDataInterfaceSkeletalMesh_BoneSam.GetFilteredSocketOrBoneCountDesc: Gets the total filtered socket and bone count from the DI's list.
NiagaraDataInterfaceSkeletalMesh_BoneSam.GetFilteredSocketTransformDesc: Gets the transform for the socket at the passed index in the DI's filtered socket list. If the Source component is set it will respect the Relative Transform Space as well..
NiagaraDataInterfaceSkeletalMesh_BoneSam.GetOptionalSkinnedBoneDataDesc: Returns skinning dependant data for the pased bone in local space. All outputs are optional and you will incur zero to minimal cost if they are not connected.
NiagaraDataInterfaceSkeletalMesh_BoneSam.GetSkinnedBoneDataDesc: Returns skinning dependant data for the pased bone in local space. Interpolated between this frame and the previous based on passed interpolation factor. All outputs are optional and you will incur zero to minimal cost if they are not connected.
NiagaraDataInterfaceSkeletalMesh_BoneSam.GetOptionalSkinnedBoneDataWSDesc: Returns skinning dependant data for the pased bone in world space. All outputs are optional and you will incur zero to minimal cost if they are not connected.
NiagaraDataInterfaceSkeletalMesh_BoneSam.GetSkinnedBoneDataWSDesc: Returns skinning dependant data for the pased bone in world space. Interpolated between this frame and the previous based on passed interpolation factor. All outputs are optional and you will incur zero to minimal cost if they are not connected.
NiagaraDataInterfaceSkeletalMesh_BoneSam.GetBoneCountDesc: Returns the number of bones in the skeletal mesh.
NiagaraDataInterfaceSkeletalMesh_BoneSam.GetFilteredSocketCountDesc: Returns the number of filtered Sockets in the DI list.
NiagaraDataInterfaceSkeletalMesh_BoneSam.GetFilteredBoneCountDesc: Returns the number of filtered bones in the DI list.
NiagaraDataInterfaceSkeletalMesh_BoneSam.GetUnfilteredBoneCountDesc: Returns the number of unfiltered bones (i.e. the exclusion of filtered bones) in the DI list.

NiagaraDataInterfaceSkeletalMesh_Triangl.IsValidDesc: Determine if this tri coordinate's triangle index is valid for this mesh. Note that this only checks the mesh index buffer size and does not include any filtering settings.
NiagaraDataInterfaceSkeletalMesh_Triangl.GetOptionalSkinnedDataDesc: Returns skinning dependant data for the pased MeshTriCoord in local space. All outputs are optional and you will incur zerp minimal cost if they are not connected.
NiagaraDataInterfaceSkeletalMesh_Triangl.GetSkinnedDataDesc: Returns skinning dependant data for the pased MeshTriCoord in local space. Interpolates between previous and current frame. All outputs are optional and you will incur zerp minimal cost if they are not connected.
NiagaraDataInterfaceSkeletalMesh_Triangl.GetOptionalSkinnedDataWSDesc: Returns skinning dependant data for the pased MeshTriCoord in world space. All outputs are optional and you will incur zerp minimal cost if they are not connected.
NiagaraDataInterfaceSkeletalMesh_Triangl.GetSkinnedDataWSDesc: Returns skinning dependant data for the pased MeshTriCoord in world space. Interpolates between previous and current frame. All outputs are optional and you will incur zerp minimal cost if they are not connected.
NiagaraDataInterfaceSkeletalMesh_Triangl.GetTriCoordVetsName: Takes the TriangleIndex from a MeshTriCoord and returns the vertices for that triangle.

NiagaraDataInterfaceSkeletalMesh_VertexS.GetSkinnedDataDesc: Returns skinning dependant data for the pased vertex in local space. All outputs are optional and you will incur zero to minimal cost if they are not connected.
NiagaraDataInterfaceSkeletalMesh_VertexS.GetSkinnedDataWSDesc: Returns skinning dependant data for the pased vertex in world space. All outputs are optional and you will incur zero to minimal cost if they are not connected.

NiagaraOpInfo.Reciprocal Fast Desc: 12-bits of accuracy, but faster. Result = 1 / A using Newton/Raphson approximation.
NiagaraOpInfo.Noise Desc: A continuous pseudo random noise function.
NiagaraOpInfo.Angle Desc: Angle as specified by the period range.
NiagaraOpInfo.Reciprocal Desc: More accurate than Reciprocal Fast. Result = 1 / A
NiagaraOpInfo.MatrixVector Mul Desc: Multiplies a matrix by a vector4.
NiagaraOpInfo.Fmod Desc Fast: Result = A % B. May be less precise than regular FMod.
NiagaraOpInfo.Pow Desc: Result = pow(A, B). When A < 0, it will be clamped to 0.
NiagaraOpInfo.Seeded Float Rand Desc: Returns a deterministic random float value between 0 and Max.
NiagaraOpInfo.Seeded Integer Rand Desc: Returns a deterministic random integer value between 0 and Max-1.
NiagaraOpInfo.Seeded Rand Desc: Returns a deterministic random value between 0 and A.
NiagaraOpInfo.HashInt Desc: Returns a hashed value for the given inputs. The output is in the range 0 to (2^31 - 1).
NiagaraOpInfo.HashFloat Desc: Returns a hashed value for the given inputs. The result is normalized to the range 0 (inclusive) to 1 (exclusive).
NiagaraOpInfo.Rand Float Desc: Returns a non-deterministic random float value between 0 and Max
NiagaraOpInfo.Rand Integer Desc: Returns a non-deterministic random integer value between 0 and Max-1
NiagaraOpInfo.Rand Desc: Returns a non-deterministic random value between 0 and A.
NiagaraOpInfo.SpawnInterp Desc: Returns the fraction used for interpolated spawning. i.e. A fraction defining where this particle was spawned between this frame and the last.
NiagaraOpInfo.ExexIndex Desc: Returns the index of this particle in the current execution. For example, in a spawn script this gives the index of the particle being spawned which can be used to interpolate it's position.
NiagaraOpInfo.Length Desc: Returns the length of the passed value.
NiagaraOpInfo.Transpose Desc: Returns the trasnpose of the passd matrix.
NiagaraOpInfo.Ceil Desc: Rounds A to the nearest integer higher than A.
NiagaraOpInfo.Floor Desc: Rounds A to the nearest integer lower than A.
NiagaraOpInfo.Round Desc: Rounds A to the nearest integer.
NiagaraOpInfo.BitLShift Desc: Shifts A left by B bits, padding with zeroes on the right. B should be between 0 and 31 or there will be undefined behavior.
NiagaraOpInfo.BitRShift Desc: Shifts A right by B bits, taking the sign bit and propagating it to fill in on left (i.e. negative numbers fill with 1's, positive fill with 0's. B should be between 0 and 31 or there will be undefined behavior.
NiagaraOpInfo.TransformPosition Desc: Transforms a Vector3 as a position.
NiagaraOpInfo.TransformVector Desc: Transforms a Vector3 as a vector.
NiagaraOpInfo.Period Desc: Value in which a complete rotation has occurred.

NiagaraScriptVersionWidget.NiagaraManageVersionInfoHeader:
Here you can see and manage available script versions. Adding versions allows you to make changes without breaking existing assets.
The exposed version is the one that users will see when adding the module, function or dynamic input to the stack. If the exposed version has a higher major version than the one used in an asset, the user will see a prompt to upgrade to the new version.
NiagaraScriptVersionWidget.NiagaraManageVersionInfoHeaderDisabled:
Versioning is not yet enabled for this script. Enabling versioning allows you to make changes to the module without breaking exising usages. But it also forces users to manually upgrade to new versions, as changes are no longer pushed out automatically.

Do you want to enable versioning for this script? This will convert the current script to version 1.0 and automatically expose it.

NiagaraStackViewModel.ParticleUpdateGroupTooltip:
Called every frame per particle. Modules in this stage should update new values for this frame.
Modules are executed in order from top to bottom of the stack.
NiagaraStackViewModel.ParticleSpawnGroupTooltip:
Called once per created particle. Modules in this stage should set up initial values for each particle.
If "Use Interpolated Spawning" is set, we will also run the Particle Update stage after the Particle Spawn stage.
Modules are executed in order from top to bottom of the stack.

NiagaraStackViewModel.EmitterUpdateGroupTooltip:
Occurs every Emitter tick on the CPU. Modules in this stage should compute values for parameters for Particle Update or Spawning this frame.
Modules are executed in order from top to bottom of the stack.
NiagaraStackViewModel.SystemUpdateGroupToolTip:
Occurs every Emitter tick on the CPU.Modules in this stage should compute values for parameters for emitter or particle update or spawning this frame.
Modules are executed in order from top to bottom of the stack.
NiagaraStackViewModel.EmitterSpawnGroupTooltip:
Occurs once at Emitter creation on the CPU. Modules in this stage should initialize defaults and/or do initial setup.
Modules are executed in order from top to bottom of the stack.
NiagaraStackViewModel.SystemSpawnGroupToolTip:
Occurs once at System creation on the CPU. Modules in this stage should initialize defaults and/or do initial setup.
Modules are executed in order from top to bottom of the stack.

OculusRift.CCommandText_Cubemap:
Oculus Rift specific extension.
Captures a cubemap for Oculus Home.
Optional arguments (default is zero for all numeric arguments):
  xoff=<float> -- X axis offset from the origin
  yoff=<float> -- Y axis offset
  zoff=<float> -- Z axis offset
  yaw=<float>  -- the direction to look into (roll and pitch is fixed to zero)
  mobile       -- Generate a Mobile format cubemap
    (height of the captured cubemap will be 1024 instead of 2048 pixels)

OculusToolWidget.DynamicLightsHeader:
<RichTextBlock.Bold>Dynamic Lights:</>
The following lights are not static. They will use dynamic lighting instead of lightmaps, and will be much more expensive on the GPU. (Most of the cost will show up in the GPU profiler as ShadowDepths and ShadowProjectonOnOpaque.) In some cases they will also give superior results. This is a fidelity-performance tradeoff. <a href="https://docs.unrealengine.com/en-us/Engine/Rendering/LightingAndShadows/LightMobility" id="HyperlinkDecorator">Read more.</>
Fixes: select the light and change its mobility to stationary to pre-compute its lighting. You will need to rebuild lightmaps. Alternatively, you can disable Cast Shadows.
OculusToolWidget.PostProcessHeader:
<RichTextBlock.Bold>Post-Processing Settings:</>
The below settings all refer to your project's post-processing settings. Post-processing can be very expensive in VR, so we recommend disabling many expensive post-processing effects. You can fine-tune your post-processing settings with a Post Process Volume. <a href="https://docs.unrealengine.com/en-us/Platforms/VR/VRPerformance" id="HyperlinkDecorator">Read more.</>.
OculusToolWidget.ShaderPermutationHeader:
<RichTextBlock.Bold>Shader Permutation Reduction:</>
The below settings all refer to your project's shader permutation settings.
OculusToolWidget.RestartRequired: <RichTextBlock.TextHighlight>Restart required:You have made changes that require an editor restart to take effect.</>
OculusToolWidget.SupportDashDescription: Dash support is not enabled. Click to enable it, but make sure to handle the appropriate focus events. <a href="https://developer.oculus.com/documentation/unreal/latest/concepts/unreal-dash/" id="HyperlinkDecorator">Read more.</>
OculusToolWidget.MobileShaderStaticAndCSMShadowReceiversB: Disable Support Combined Static and CSM Shadowing
OculusToolWidget.MobileShaderAllowDistanceFieldShadowsBut: Disable Support Support Distance Field Shadows
OculusToolWidget.AndroidQuestArchButton: Enable Android Arm64 CPU architecture support
OculusToolWidget.MobileMSAADescription: Enable Mobile MSAA 4x to get higher quality antialiasing at a reasonable cost on mobile codepaths.
OculusToolWidget.MobileMultiViewDescription: Enable mobile multi-view and direct mobile multi-view to significantly reduce CPU overhead.
OculusToolWidget.StartInVRDescription: Enable the "Start in VR" setting to ensure your app starts in VR. (You can also ignore this and pass -vr at the command line.)
OculusToolWidget.ForwardShadingDescription: Forward shading is not enabled for this project. Forward shading is often better suited for VR rendering. <a href="https://docs.unrealengine.com/en-us/Engine/Performance/ForwardRenderer" id="HyperlinkDecorator">Read more.</>
OculusToolWidget.InstancedStereoDescription: Instanced stereo is not enabled for this project. Instanced stereo substantially reduces draw calls, and improves rendering performance.
OculusToolWidget.LensFlareDescription: Lens flare is enabled. It can be expensive, and exhibit visible artifacts in VR.
OculusToolWidget.MobileHDRDescription: Mobile HDR has performance and stability issues in VR. We strongly recommend disabling it.
OculusToolWidget.AndroidQuestArchDescription: Oculus Quest store requires 64-bit applications. <a href="https://developer.oculus.com/blog/quest-submission-policy-update-64-bit-by-default/" id="HyperlinkDecorator">Read more.</>
OculusToolWidget.MobileNumDynamicPointLightsButton: Set Max Movable Spotlights / Point Lights to 0
OculusToolWidget.AndroidPackagingDescription: Some mobile packaging settings need to be fixed. (SDK versions, and FullScreen Immersive settings.) <a href="https://developer.oculus.com/documentation/unreal/latest/concepts/unreal-quick-start-guide-go/" id="HyperlinkDecorator">Read more.</>
OculusToolWidget.TargetPlatform: Target Platform: (This setting changes which recommendations are displayed, but does NOT modify your project.)
OculusToolWidget.AntiAliasingDescription: The forward render supports MSAA and Temporal anti-aliasing. Enable one of these for the best VR visual-performance tradeoff. (This button will enable temporal anti-aliasing. You can enable MSAA instead in Edit -> Project Settings -> Rendering.)
OculusToolWidget.AndroidManifestDescription: You need to select a target device in "Package for Oculus Mobile device" for all mobile apps. <a href="https://developer.oculus.com/documentation/unreal/latest/concepts/unreal-quick-start-guide-go/" id="HyperlinkDecorator">Read more.</>
OculusToolWidget.AllowStaticLightingDescription: Your project does not allow static lighting. You should only disallow static lighting if you intend for your project to be 100% dynamically lit.
OculusToolWidget.MobileNumDynamicPointLightsDescription: Your project does not contain any movable lights. Max Movable Spotlights / Point Lights can be set to 0 to reduce shader permutations.
OculusToolWidget.MobileShaderAllowMovableDirectionalLight: Your project does not contain any movable lights. Support Movable Directional Lights can be disabled to reduce shader permutations.
OculusToolWidget.MobileMovableSpotlightsDescription: Your project does not contain any movable lights. Support Movable Spotlights can be disabled to reduce shader permutations.
OculusToolWidget.MobileShaderStaticAndCSMShadowReceiversD: Your project does not contain any stationary lights. Support Combined Static and CSM Shadowing can be disabled to reduce shader permutations.

RenderDocPlugin.HelpMessage:
<LargeText>Hello and thank you for trying out the UE4 RenderDoc plugin!</>

This plugin will allow you to capture rendering operations in the engine, and inspect them using RenderDoc.
There are three ways of capturing a frame:
* You can press the <NormalText.Important>green capture button</> in the top right of any viewport.
* You can run the <NormalText.Important>renderdoc.CaptureFrame</> console command. This will work anywhere and is very useful for capturing frames in packaged builds.
* You can use the capture hotkey (<NormalText.Important>Alt+F12</>). Please note that the hotkey is only active in editor windows and Play-In-Editor sessions.

If you are having trouble with not getting enough data in your captures, consider checking out the capture settings.
They can be found under <NormalText.Important>[Edit]->[Project Settings...]->[Plugins/RenderDoc]</>. All settings have tooltips that detail what they do.

A good place to start learning graphics debugging in UE4 is the <a id="browser" href="https://docs.unrealengine.com/latest/INT/Programming/Rendering/ShaderDevelopment" style="Hyperlink">Epic Rendering FAQ</>
It contains information on what CVar/project settings you should set when debugging shaders to get access to as much data as possible.

If you have any questions or suggestions regarding the plugin, please contact me via email or my github page:
<NormalText.Important>temaran (at) gmail (dot) com</>
<a id="browser" href="https://github.com/Temaran/UE4RenderDocPlugin" style="Hyperlink">https://github.com/Temaran/UE4RenderDocPlugin</>

I would also like to give major shoutouts to BaldurK, the author of RenderDoc:
<a id="browser" href="https://github.com/baldurk" style="Hyperlink">https://github.com/baldurk</>
And Slomp, who has made many great contributions to the project:
<a id="browser" href="https://github.com/slomp" style="Hyperlink">https://github.com/slomp</>

SNiagaraStackRowPerfWidget.GroupHeaderUpdateGPUTooltip:
This is the total GPU runtime cost of the combined spawn and update script call.
There are no individual module costs because the gpu stats cannot be measured on that level.
SNiagaraStackRowPerfWidget.GroupHeaderSimStageGPUTooltip:
This is the total GPU runtime cost of the simulation stage script.
If the simulation stage has more than one iteration then this is the combined sum of all iterations.
SNiagaraStackRowPerfWidget.GroupHeaderEmitterTooltip:
This is the total runtime cost of the emitter script and its module calls.
Note that the module calls do not add up to 100% because the script itself has some overhead as well.
SNiagaraStackRowPerfWidget.GroupHeaderTooltip:
This is the total runtime cost of the script and its module calls.
Note that the module calls do not add up to 100% because the script itself has some overhead as well.
SNiagaraStackRowPerfWidget.GroupHeaderSpawnTooltip:
This is the total runtime cost of the spawn script and its module calls.
Note that the module calls do not add up to 100% because the script itself has some overhead as well.
When interpolated spawn is enabled, this also includes the cost of running the update script on the spawned particles.
SNiagaraStackRowPerfWidget.GroupHeaderSystemTooltip:
This is the total runtime cost of the system script and its module calls.
Since the emitter scripts are embedded in the system scripts, they are part of this cost as well and visualized in a different color.
Note that the module calls do not add up to 100% because the system script itself has some overhead as well.
SNiagaraStackRowPerfWidget.ModuleEntryTooltip:
This shows the module runtime cost in percent.
The displayed percentage relates only to the parent script, not the whole emitter.
The module cost does not include work from DI calls to other threads, e.g. async collision traces.
SNiagaraStackRowPerfWidget.EmitterEntryTooltip:
This shows the module runtime cost in percent.
The displayed percentages relate only to the parent emitter script, not the whole system script.
Note that the module calls do not add up to 100% because the emitter script itself has some overhead as well.
SNiagaraStackRowPerfWidget.SystemEntryTooltip:
This shows the module runtime cost in percent.
The displayed percentages relate to the full system script, which has the emitter scripts embedded.
Note that even without emitter cost, the module calls do not add up to 100% because the system script itself has some overhead as well.

SSlateTraceFlags.InvalidateWidgetReasonFlagsTooltip:
L : Layout : The widget desired size changed.
P : Paint : The widget needs repainting but nothing affecting its size.
U : Volatile : The widget volatility changed.
C : Child Order : A child was added or removed (this implies layout).
R : Render Transform : The widget render transform changed.
V : Visibility : The widget visibility changed (this implies layout).
SSlateTraceFlags.UpdateFlagsTooltip:
U : Tick : The widget was updated/ticked.
T : Active Timer Update : The widget had an active timer.
P : Repaint : The widget was dirty and was repainted.
V : Volatile Paint : The widget was volatile and was repainted.

STestSuite.WidgetDecoratorTooltip: With the <RichText.TextHighlight>Widget Decorator</> you can <RichText.TextHighlight>inline any widget</> in your text!
STestSuite.RichText.HowItWorks: What does it do? The SRichTextBlock uses a concept called Decorators to introduce new font styles, images, animation and even whole interactive widgets inline with the text. Slate comes with a couple Decorators out of the box: • Text Decorator • Image Decorator • Widget Decorator • Hyperlink Decorator What about options? Of course you can always introduce your own Decorators by implementing ITextDecorator. This will give you full customization in how your text or widget is styled. Besides the power of Decorators the SRichTextBlock comes equipped with Margin support, Left-Center-Right Text Justification, a Line Height Scalar and Highlighting. How does the markup work? Well the markup parser is customizable so you can adjust the markup anyway you'd like by providing your own parser. The parser that comes with Slate though uses a syntax very similar to xml. • <TextBlockStyleName>Your text content</> • <img src="SlateBrushStyleName"/> • <a id="YourCustomId"/>Your hyperlink text</> If you ever want to use the markup syntax as actual text you can escape the markup using xml style escapes. For example: • < < • > > • " " But you only need to escape these characters when a set of them match actual syntax so this isn't generally an issue. Are there any catches? There are still plenty of things the SRichTextBlock doesn't currently support. The most notable lacking feature is not having the ability to flow text around images or widgets.
STestSuite.RichTextEdit.HowItWorks:
<RichText.TextHighlight>SMultiLineEditableText</> utilizes the power of text marshallers to control how the source text is displayed, and the two editors below are demonstrating the <RichText.TextHighlight>FRichTextLayoutMarshaller</> and <RichText.TextHighlight>FRichTextSyntaxHighlighterTextLayoutMarshaller</> implementations.

You can use the toolbar to control the style of the text in the rich-text editor, or you can directly edit the source text (demonstrating live injection of style information) to update the rich-text view.

STestSuite.MultiLineTextTest:
He has refused his Assent to Laws, the most wholesome and necessary for the public good.
He has forbidden his Governors to pass Laws of immediate and pressing importance, unless suspended in their operation till his Assent should be obtained; and when so suspended, he has utterly neglected to attend to them.
He has refused to pass other Laws for the accommodation of large districts of people, unless those people would relinquish the right of Representation in the Legislature, a right inestimable to them and formidable to tyrants only.

He has called together legislative bodies at places unusual, uncomfortable, and distant from the depository of their public Records, for the sole purpose of fatiguing them into compliance with his measures.
He has dissolved Representative Houses repeatedly, for opposing with manly firmness his invasions on the rights of the people.
He has refused for a long time, after such dissolutions, to cause others to be elected; whereby the Legislative powers, incapable of Annihilation, have returned to the People at large for their exercise; the State remaining in the mean time exposed to all the dangers of invasion from without, and convulsions within.
He has endeavoured to prevent the population of these States; for that purpose obstructing the Laws for Naturalization of Foreigners; refusing to pass others to encourage their migrations hither, and raising the conditions of new Appropriations of Lands.

UNiagaraDataInterface2DArrayTexture.TextureDimsDesc: Get the dimensions of mip 0 of the texture.
UNiagaraDataInterface2DArrayTexture.TextureSampleVolumeTextureDesc: Sample the specified mip level of the input texture at the specified UVW coordinates. Where W is the slice to sample (0,1,2, etc) and UV are the coordinates into the slice.

UNiagaraDataInterfaceCubeTexture.TextureDimsDesc: Get the dimensions of mip 0 of the texture.
UNiagaraDataInterfaceCubeTexture.TextureSampleCubeTextureDesc: Sample the specified mip level of the input cube texture at the specified UVW coordinates

UNiagaraDataInterfaceTexture.TextureDimsDesc: Get the dimensions of mip 0 of the texture.
UNiagaraDataInterfaceTexture.TextureSamplePseudoVolumeTextureDesc:
Return a pseudovolume texture sample.
Useful for simulating 3D texturing with a 2D texture or as a texture flipbook with lerped transitions.
Treats 2d layout of frames as a 3d texture and performs bilinear filtering by blending with an offset Z frame.
Texture = Input Texture Object storing Volume Data
UVW = Input float3 for Position, 0 - 1
XYNumFrames = Input float for num frames in x, y directions
TotalNumFrames = Input float for num total frames
MipMode = Sampling mode : 0 = use miplevel, 1 = use UV computed gradients, 2 = Use gradients(default = 0)
MipLevel = MIP level to use in mipmode = 0 (default 0)
DDX, DDY = Texture gradients in mipmode = 2
UNiagaraDataInterfaceTexture.TextureSampleTexture2DDesc: Sample mip level 0 of the input 2d texture at the specified UV coordinates. The UV origin (0,0) is in the upper left hand corner of the image.

UNiagaraDataInterfaceVolumeTexture.TextureDimsDesc: Get the dimensions of mip 0 of the texture.
UNiagaraDataInterfaceVolumeTexture.TextureSampleVolumeTextureDesc: Sample the specified mip level of the input 3d texture at the specified UVW coordinates. The UVW origin (0, 0, 0) is in the bottom left hand corner of the volume.

UnrealEd.GeomModifier_Clip.Tooltip: Given a dividing plane, cut the geometry into two pieces, optionally discarding one of them. This operation only works in an orthographic viewport.  Define the vertices of the dividing plane with the space bar, and press Enter to apply.

UnrealEd.GeomModifier_Create.Tooltip: Creates a new polygon from the selected vertices. The vertices must be selected in clockwise order to create a poly with an outward facing normal.

UnrealEd.GeomModifier_Delete.Tooltip: Deletes the selected geometry elements (vertices, edges or polygons).

UnrealEd.GeomModifier_Edit.Tooltip: Select faces, edges, or vertices directly in the viewport.  Use the manipulator to translate, rotate or scale existing geometry.

UnrealEd.GeomModifier_Extrude.Tooltip: Moves the selected geometry element forward, creating new geometry behind it if necessary.

UnrealEd.GeomModifier_Flip.Tooltip: Flips the normal of the selected polygon so that it faces the other way.

UnrealEd.GeomModifier_Lathe.Tooltip: Take Brush Shapes (created via the Pen Tool with CreateBrushShape enabled) and revolve them around the pivot point to create curved brushes.  Create a pivot using ALT + MMB Drag, then switch to a Top-Down Viewport and hit Apply.

UnrealEd.GeomModifier_Optimize.Tooltip: Optimizes the selected geometry by merging together any polygons which can be formed into a single convex polygon.

UnrealEd.GeomModifier_Pen.Split_Tooltip: Create blocking volumes or freeform geometry by creating a series of anchor points.  Note, you must be in a 2D viewport with focus to use the pen tool.  Create at least 3 anchor points in an orthographic viewport using the spacebar to commit an anchor point.  Complete the shape by creating an anchor on top of the first one.  Use bAutoExtrude with ExtrudeDepth to create a 3D shape.
UnrealEd.GeomModifier_Pen.Tooltip: Create new geometry by drawing the vertices directly into an orthographic viewport. Press space bar to place a vertex, and Enter to close the polygon.

UnrealEd.GeomModifier_Triangulate.Tooltip: Break the selected polygons down into triangles.

UnrealEd.GeomModifier_Turn.Tooltip: Given a selected edge common to two triangles, turn the edge so that it is connected to the previously unconnected vertices.

UnrealEd.GeomModifier_Weld.Tooltip: Merge all selected vertices to the first selected vertex.

UPlaneCutTool.PlaneCutMultipleAssetWithSameSource: WARNING: Multiple meshes in your selection use the same source asset! UPolygonOnMeshTool.PolygonOnMeshToolDescription: Cut the Mesh with a swept Polygon, creating a Hole or new Polygroup. Use the Draw Polygon button to draw a custom polygon on the work plane. Ctrl-click to reposition the work plane.

UProjectToTargetTool.ProjectToTargetToolDescription: Incrementally deform the first selected mesh towards the second, while applying Remeshing. This can be used to improve the accuracy of shrink-wrapping strategies.

URemeshMeshTool.OnStartTool: Retriangulate the selected Mesh. Use the Boundary Constraints to preserve mesh borders. Enable Discard Attributes to ignore UV/Normal Seams.

URemoveOccludedTrianglesTool.RemoveOccludedTrianglesToolDescription: Remove triangles that are fully contained within the selected Meshes, and hence cannot be visible with opaque shading.
URemoveOccludedTrianglesTool.JacketingMultipleAssetWithSameSource: WARNING: Multiple meshes in your selection use the same source asset!  Triangles will be conservatively removed from these meshes only when they are occluded in every selected instance.

URevolveBoundaryTool.NoBoundaryLoops: This mesh does not have any boundary loops to display and revolve. Delete some faces or use a different mesh.
URevolveBoundaryTool.OnStartRevolveBoundaryTool: This tool revolves the mesh boundary around the axis to create a new mesh. Ctrl+click will reposition the revolution axis, potentially aligning it with an edge.
URevolveBoundaryTool.OnStartRevolveBoundaryToolMultipleBounda: Your mesh has multiple boundaries- Click the one you wish to use

UVoxelBlendMeshesTool.VoxelBlendMeshesToolDescription: Compute a volumetric Blend of the input meshes, controlled by the Blend Power/Falloff. UVs, sharp edges, and small/thin features will be lost. Increase Voxel Count to enhance accuracy.

UVoxelCSGMeshesTool.OnStartTool: This Tool computes a CSG Boolean of the input meshes using voxelization techniques. UVs, sharp edges, and small/thin features will be lost. Increase Voxel Count to enhance accuracy.

UVoxelMorphologyMeshesTool.OnStartTool: Apply Morphological operations to the input meshes to create a new Mesh, using voxelization techniques. UVs, sharp edges, and small/thin features will be lost. Increase Voxel Count to enhance accuracy.

UVoxelSolidifyMeshesTool.VoxelSolidifyMeshesToolDescription: Create a new closed/solid shell mesh that wraps the input meshes. Holes will automatically be filled, controlled by the Winding Threshold. UVs, sharp edges, and small/thin features will be lost. Increase Voxel Count to enhance accuracy.

UWeldMeshEdgesTool.WeldMeshEdgesToolDescription: Weld overlapping/identical border edges of the selected Mesh, by merging the vertices.
